prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for wearing earbuds and occasionally checking my phone during a church mass that I am forced to go to even though I am an atheist?
My parents have recently had a interest in going to church for the past month or so, so every Sunday, they force me to attend mass with them. I have told them multiple times that I don't believe in what they believe, but they brush it off and force me to come anyways. So this time, I brought earbuds and put on an album to listen to (Stokeley by Ski Mask the Slump God is great; listen to it) because I wanted to listen to my music instead. I would also text my friend every 15 minutes or so. During the entire mass, my mom shot me dirty looks the whole time and later told me on the ride home that I have a horribly negative attitude and that I should enjoy things more (even though I have told them countless times that I don't believe in what they do and dislike attending church.

Am I just being a bitch or are my parents at fault?
"""

I think the author is in the wrong but curious what you think.
Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

So, the answer might hinge on whether the parent's actions are more at fault. If the parents are wrong for forcing attendance, then the child's response, while perhaps disrespectful, is a reaction to that. Therefore, the child isn't in the wrong primarily. I think the key here is that the parents are forcing attendance against the child's will, which is problematic. The child's actions are a way to deal with the situation they're in. While the child's behavior might not be the most respectful, the root issue is the parents' insistence on forcing attendance. Therefore, the child is not in the wrong, as they are reacting to the parents' actions. So the answer would be B, No, the author is not in the wrong.
